newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: BMC Software of the U.S. charts Asia growth.
newsitem.headline: BMC Software of the U.S. charts Asia growth.

text.p: U.S. database management products company BMC Software plans a vigorous Asian expansion after opening a series of offices in the past 18 months, Hugh Sutherland, BMC managing director for Asia, said on Thursday.
He told Reuters in an interview that along with the new offices BMC had opened a research and development centre in Singapore and extended partnerships to boost regional business.
For the fiscal year ending March 1997, BMC aimed to double its Asian contribution to worldwide revenue to 15 percent from seven percent, he said.
Based on corporate projections of a 25 percent increase in global revenue to about US$535 million for fiscal 1997, Asian revenue could be around US$80 million.
"BMC's goal is to replicate our success in the U.S. and Europe, to be the premier provider of systems management products," he said.

Sutherland said the company's shift over the past two or three years into a broad provider of management tools from a pure seller of mainframe products had made it vital to have stronger relationships with key Asian organisations.
Otherwise, opportunities in Asia -- which for BMC excludes Japan, Australia and New Zealand -- could be missed.
BMC now has offices in Singapore, Korea and Hong Kong and is opening an office in Malaysia in the first quarter of 1997.
It uses Hong Kong a base for tapping China's market and has a distributor in Beijing which aims to operate across the country.
BMC also capitalises on its partnerships with big players such as Hewlett-Packard Co, Digitial Equipment Corp, Oracle Corp and Sybase Inc to extend its reach, Sutherland said.
About 60 percent of BMC's Asian business is mainframe-based and should move to 50-50 with open systems in the next two years, he said.
He said the mainframe computer business was not a sunset sector, adding that it brought in 85 percent of BMC's licensing revenue of US$269 million for the fiscal year ended March 1996.
In Asia, markets such as South Korea and China, along with a stream of maintenance revenue, would keep the mainframe business buoyant at least over the next two years, he said.
BMC's Asian open systems growth mirrored hefty growth experienced on a global basis in the second quarter ended September 1996, he said.
BMC set up a Singapore R&D centre in July which aimed to develop open systems products in Asian languages.
"We view that it is essential for us to have internationalised products to effectively address the North Asian markets," Sutherland said.
The first such products, expected by the end of March, will be for Japan and Korea, followed by products for Taiwan and China by mid-1997. Sutherland declined to say how much he expected to ship.
He said BMC expected these Asian-customised products to make "positive contributions" to earnings within two years.
